Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Bioarchaeology Research on the Impacts of Colonization on Local Population Health

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. As such, it has both scientific and societal benefits, and it integrates research and education. The eight-week international REU Site brings eight undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds to Sicily, Italy for four weeks to collect data from ancient human skeletons, and back to the United State for four weeks to work in the research laboratories at the University of Georgia. Students complete independent research projects relating to the health, activity patterns, diet, and genetic relatedness of people at the Greek colony and battlefield of Himera to better understand the biocultural consequences of culture contact in the past. Globalization is ever-increasing and often resembles colonization with its spread of ideas and people to developing nations. REU students will learn first-hand about deep roots and biological dimensions of interactions between diverse populations. Participants receive specialized field and lab training in archaeological chemistry, anatomy, research design, and data analysis. Students will leave the REU with greater technical and analytical skills, better preparedness for graduate study and professional careers, and heightened awareness of global issues relating to population contact, inequality, human conflict, and health transitions. These skills are foundational for improving global citizenship and stewardship in any career.

To promote scientific literacy and global engagement among undergraduates, this three-year REU Site integrates students as junior partners of the Bioarchaeology of Mediterranean Colonies Project, a cross-disciplinary, international research program that has brought undergraduate students to the Mediterranean for the past three summers. REU students generate new anthropological knowledge related to human adaptation and the impacts of culture contact in the ancient Mediterranean. Student projects focus on the more than 12,000 skeletons unearthed at Himera, which in the 7-5th centuries B.C. was the site of Greek colonizing efforts and violent battles. Himera represents an early epicenter of rising ethnic inequality. REU students plan and execute independent research projects exploring biocultural impacts of culture contact in Greek Sicily, including changes in diet, activity patterns, health, mobility, and genetic admixture, using stable isotope biogeochemistry, molecular anthropology, osteology, paleopathology and statistical analysis. Students collect bioarchaeological data from human skeletons at Sicily for four weeks, and spend the remaining four weeks at the University of Georgia (UGA) apprenticed in the UGA Bioarchaeology and Biochemistry Laboratory, analyzing field specimens. REU students participate in focused workshops and seminars, and work with dedicated mentors, receiving hands-on training for research projects. Through these activities, students (1) learn archaeological and anthropological field and lab methods, (2) learn from both American and Italian scholars, (3) visit museums and archaeological sites on Sicily, (4) design, execute, and present independent research projects that make substantive contributions to anthropology, (5) live in the city of Palermo, Italy where they will interact with Italian students and citizens, and (6) remain in close contact with faculty mentors for a full academic year to publish their results and present at international conferences. Two PhD student affiliates will gain mentorship training. REU students will leave better prepared to pursue and succeed in graduate school, excel in STEM careers, and be more globally engaged citizens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This eight-week international REU Site brought 23 undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds to Sicily, Italy for four weeks to collect data from ancient human skeletons, and back to the United State for four weeks to work in the research laboratories at the University of Georgia in the summers of 2016-2018. Student participants designed and executed independent research projects that related to the health, activity patterns, diet, and genetic relatedness of people at the Greek colony and battlefield of Himera to better understand the biocultural consequences of culture contact in the past. Each student formulated a hypothesis, evaluated and applied basic bioarchaeological methods and theoretical frameworks in designing the means of testing their hypothesis, collected data in the field and in the lab, and applied quantitative and/or qualitative methods of analyzing human skeletons in archaeological contexts (for example, to determine age, sex, stature, diet, and physiological stress). By critically examining the unique perspective offered by human remains, our 2016-2018 REU students used evidence to support new interpretations of the past.

 

This REU Site helped to advance anthropological understanding of the impacts of culture contact. Student findings suggest that people of different cultural backgrounds lived, and were buried together at the Greek colony of Himera. Students were able to trace incipient social inequality in the ancient Mediterranean by examining bioarchaeological data in conjunction with archaeological evidence and historical records, and demonstrate that differences in burial style and the location of burial (either in the East or West necropolis) was associated with differential health outcomes during life. Students were also able to confirm historical accounts of two epic battles in ancient history, the Battles of Himera. Ancient historians write of alliances that aided Himera in its victory against a Carthaginian army of hired foreign mercenaries in 480 BCE, and Himera?s loss when it fought against Carthage again in 409 BCE, this time unaided by allies. This research indicates that alliances and coalition formation were critical for success in ancient conflicts. Finally, students compared their findings from Himera to other Greek colonies across the Mediterranean, and were able to demonstrate that living in Greek mother cities was stressful for citizens, both before and after colonization. High rates of skeletal stress in people from Greek mother cities indicates that Greek colonies may have been established to relieve population pressures in Greek cities, and/or to increase the amount of resources that could be paid by Greek colonies to their mother cities in the form of tribute.

 

All except one of our students submitted abstracts and presented their research at national anthropological conferences, where they shared their results with the academic community. REU students applied professional research and communication skills through interacting with academic professionals, peers, and members of another culture in the course of field and laboratory collaboration. Pre- and post-assessment surveys indicate that the program increased student confidence in problem-solving, formulating research questions, analyzing data, understanding the research process, using statistics, writing in a scientific style, working collaboratively, including with people from other cultural backgrounds, identifying limitations of research methods and designs, working in a lab, understanding theory, making connections among scientific disciplines, and understanding the relevance of research to their coursework. Many of our students are currently in graduate programs and/or working in scientific disciplines. However, regardless of what careers the students ultimately pursue, the skills they developed as part of the REU Site: Bioarchaeology Research on the Impacts of Colonization on Local Population Health will make them more scientifically literate citizens.
